trans-unit.source: Store project code in source control | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Store project code in source control | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to store your server script files and modules in a local Git repo on your computer.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to store your server script files and modules in a local Git repo on your computer.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use the source control provided by Azure Mobile Services to store your server scripts.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use the source control provided by Azure Mobile Services to store your server scripts.

trans-unit.source: Scripts and other JavaScript backend code files can be promoted from your local Git repository to your production mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Scripts and other JavaScript backend code files can be promoted from your local Git repository to your production mobile service.

trans-unit.source: It also shows how to define shared code that can be required by multiple scripts and how to use the package.json file to add Node.js modules to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: It also shows how to define shared code that can be required by multiple scripts and how to use the package.json file to add Node.js modules to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you must have already created a mobile service by completing either the [Get started with Mobile Services] or the [Add Mobile Services to an existing app] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you must have already created a mobile service by completing either the [Get started with Mobile Services] or the [Add Mobile Services to an existing app] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Install Git on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: Install Git on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: The steps required to install Git vary between operating systems.
trans-unit.target: The steps required to install Git vary between operating systems.

trans-unit.source: See [Installing Git] for operating system specific distributions and installation guidance.
trans-unit.target: See [Installing Git] for operating system specific distributions and installation guidance.

trans-unit.source: On some operating systems, both a command-line and GUI version of Git are available.
trans-unit.target: On some operating systems, both a command-line and GUI version of Git are available.

trans-unit.source: The instructions provided in this article use the command-line version.
trans-unit.target: The instructions provided in this article use the command-line version.

trans-unit.source: Open a command-line, such as GitBash (Windows) or Bash (Unix Shell).
trans-unit.target: Open a command-line, such as GitBash (Windows) or Bash (Unix Shell).

trans-unit.source: On OS X systems you can access the command-line through the Terminal application.
trans-unit.target: On OS X systems you can access the command-line through the Terminal application.

trans-unit.source: From the command line, change to the directory where you will store your scripts.
trans-unit.target: From the command line, change to the directory where you will store your scripts.

trans-unit.source: For example, cd SourceControl.
trans-unit.target: For example, cd SourceControl.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to create a local copy of your new Git repository, replacing with the URL of the Git repository for your mobile service:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to create a local copy of your new Git repository, replacing with the URL of the Git repository for your mobile service:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, type in the user name and password that you set when you enabled source control in your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, type in the user name and password that you set when you enabled source control in your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: After successful authentication, you will see a series of responses like this:
trans-unit.target: After successful authentication, you will see a series of responses like this:

trans-unit.source: Browse to the directory from which you ran the git clone command, and notice the following directory structure:
trans-unit.target: Browse to the directory from which you ran the git clone command, and notice the following directory structure:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>4</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>4</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this case, a new directory is created with the name of the mobile service, which is the local repository for the data service.
trans-unit.target: In this case, a new directory is created with the name of the mobile service, which is the local repository for the data service.

trans-unit.source: Open the .\service\table subfolder and notice that it contains a TodoItem.json file, which is a JSON representation of the operation permissions on the TodoItem table.
trans-unit.target: Open the .\service\table subfolder and notice that it contains a TodoItem.json file, which is a JSON representation of the operation permissions on the TodoItem table.

trans-unit.source: When server scripts have been defined on this table, you will also have one or more files named TodoItem.<operation>.js that contain the scripts for the given table operation.
trans-unit.target: When server scripts have been defined on this table, you will also have one or more files named TodoItem.<operation>.js that contain the scripts for the given table operation.

trans-unit.source: Scheduler and custom API scripts are maintained in separate folders with those respective names.
trans-unit.target: Scheduler and custom API scripts are maintained in separate folders with those respective names.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Source control].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Source control].

trans-unit.source: Now that you have created your local repository, you can make changes to server scripts and push the changes back to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have created your local repository, you can make changes to server scripts and push the changes back to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the .\service\table subfolder, and if a file todoitem.insert.js files doesn't already exist, create it now.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the .\service\table subfolder, and if a file todoitem.insert.js files doesn't already exist, create it now.

trans-unit.source: Open the new file todoitem.insert.js in a text editor and paste in the following code and save your changes:
trans-unit.target: Open the new file todoitem.insert.js in a text editor and paste in the following code and save your changes:

trans-unit.source: This code simply writes the inserted item to the log.
trans-unit.target: This code simply writes the inserted item to the log.

trans-unit.source: If this file already contains code, simply add some valid JavaScript code to this file, such as a call to console.log(), then save your changes.
trans-unit.target: If this file already contains code, simply add some valid JavaScript code to this file, such as a call to console.log(), then save your changes.

trans-unit.source: In the Git command prompt, type the following command to start tracking the new script file:
trans-unit.target: In the Git command prompt, type the following command to start tracking the new script file:

trans-unit.source: Type the following command to commit changes:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command to commit changes:

trans-unit.source: Type the following command to upload the changes to the remote repository:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command to upload the changes to the remote repository:

trans-unit.source: You should see a series of commands that indicates that the commit is deployed to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: You should see a series of commands that indicates that the commit is deployed to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Back in the Management Portal, click the Data tab, then click the TodoItem table, click Script, then select the Insert operation.
trans-unit.target: Back in the Management Portal, click the Data tab, then click the TodoItem table, click Script, then select the Insert operation.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the displayed insert operation script is the same as the JavaScript code that you just uploaded to the repository.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the displayed insert operation script is the same as the JavaScript code that you just uploaded to the repository.

trans-unit.source: Mobile Services provides access to the full set of core Node.js modules, which you can use in your code by using the require function.
trans-unit.target: Mobile Services provides access to the full set of core Node.js modules, which you can use in your code by using the require function.

trans-unit.source: Your mobile service can also use Node.js modules that are not part of the core Node.js package, and you can even define your own shared code as Node.js modules.
trans-unit.target: Your mobile service can also use Node.js modules that are not part of the core Node.js package, and you can even define your own shared code as Node.js modules.

trans-unit.source: For more information about creating modules, see [Modules] in the Node.js API reference documentation.
trans-unit.target: For more information about creating modules, see [Modules] in the Node.js API reference documentation.

trans-unit.source: The recommended way to add Node.js modules to your mobile service is by adding references to the service's package.json file.
trans-unit.target: The recommended way to add Node.js modules to your mobile service is by adding references to the service's package.json file.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will add the [node-uuid] Node.js module to your mobile service by updating the package.json file.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will add the [node-uuid] Node.js module to your mobile service by updating the package.json file.

trans-unit.source: When the update is pushed to Azure, the mobile service is restarted and the module is installed.
trans-unit.target: When the update is pushed to Azure, the mobile service is restarted and the module is installed.

trans-unit.source: This module is then used to generate a new GUID value for the uuid property on inserted items.
trans-unit.target: This module is then used to generate a new GUID value for the uuid property on inserted items.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the .\service folder of your local Git repository, and open the package.json file in a text editor, and add the following field to the dependencies object:
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the .\service folder of your local Git repository, and open the package.json file in a text editor, and add the following field to the dependencies object:

trans-unit.source: This update to the package.json file will cause a restart in your mobile service after the commit is pushed.
trans-unit.target: This update to the package.json file will cause a restart in your mobile service after the commit is pushed.

trans-unit.source: Now browse to the .\service\table subfolder, open the todoitem.insert.js file and modify it as follows:
trans-unit.target: Now browse to the .\service\table subfolder, open the todoitem.insert.js file and modify it as follows:

trans-unit.source: This code adds a uuid column to the table, populating it with unique GUID identifiers.
trans-unit.target: This code adds a uuid column to the table, populating it with unique GUID identifiers.

trans-unit.source: As in the previous section, type the following command in the Git command prompt:
trans-unit.target: As in the previous section, type the following command in the Git command prompt:

trans-unit.source: This adds the new file, commits your changes, and pushes the new node-uuid module and changes to the todoitem.insert.js script to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This adds the new file, commits your changes, and pushes the new node-uuid module and changes to the todoitem.insert.js script to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have completed this tutorial you know how to store your scripts in source control.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have completed this tutorial you know how to store your scripts in source control.

trans-unit.source: Consider learning more about working with server scripts and with custom APIs:
trans-unit.target: Consider learning more about working with server scripts and with custom APIs:

trans-unit.source:
[Work with server scripts in Mobile Services]
Shows how to work with server scripts, job scheduler, and custom APIs.
trans-unit.target:
[Work with server scripts in Mobile Services]
Shows how to work with server scripts, job scheduler, and custom APIs.

trans-unit.source:
[Call a custom API from the client]
Shows how to create custom APIs that can be called from the client.
trans-unit.target:
[Call a custom API from the client]
Shows how to create custom APIs that can be called from the client.
